reviewText:
In my previous review of Asteroid Bounty Hunter, I said that the game suffered from too many issues to be worth a recommendation. A couple days later, the developer issued a patch that fixed...well...everything! Now this is a fine shootemup with several good ideas, plenty of content, and solid controls.

This is one of those games where everything you need to know, is spelled out in the title. Your job is to destroy asteroids, but apparently there's a price on your head, and bounty hunters from all over the galaxy are looking to collect. Karma, your ship, is armed with four weapons, three of which operate on cool-down timers. The strategy is in using these weapons at the right moments to avoid getting crushed by asteroids or blasted by hunters. As you complete stages and acquire experience, you can level up your weapons and shields.

Each stage plays out in the same manner. Your mission is to destroy x number of asteroids, and you're frequently attacked by bounty hunters. In my opinion, these stages are implemented in too rigid a fashion. When hunters appear, rocks stop flying at the player. By the end of the game, there are five types of hunters, but it gets pretty dull just fighting them.

However, in this version of Asteroid Bounty Hunter, two new modifiers were added, and they dramatically increase the fun-factor of this game. When you turn on the Bounty Hunter setting, hunters continously spawn every few seconds. If you can't keep up with them, you're liable to get overwhelmed. The Bullet Hell setting causes asteroids to continually assault the player, no matter how many hunters are onscreen. While it's very nice that toggling these modifiers adds a significant boost to your experience, I like them simply because they make the game a lot more dynamic and entertaining.

To really explain just how much these additions improve the game, I'll provide a couple examples. Some hunters prefer to stay on the far right side of the screen, so that they can pelt you with bullets. Since asteroids are continually flying around, they're going to block most of your shots. This means that you'll have to work harder to find openings, or focus entirely on dodging until the enemy ship flies off. There are other enemies that fire giant lasers and spin around, you can move in a circle to avoid the lasers, but that isn't always possible with everything else flying around. You either have to unload your powerful weapons to destroy these foes quickly, or trust in your shields and take the damage. As new enemy-types are introduced, the game becomes even deeper. You really have to be considerate of your options, in order to survive these dangerous challenges.

It's important to also keep in mind that if these modifiers prove to be too much for you, then turn them off. Even with my level 180+ ship, I tend to get crushed when I play the latter stages on the harder difficulties. Sometimes you'll need to grind a little and bring your weapon levels up. Being able to destroy asteroids and aliens quickly is paramount to your survival. The difficulty can become a little unbalanced when hunters are constantly pouring into the chaos, but that's the trade-off if you want the exp. multiplier bonus.

The bosses provide a nice break from the other stages. Each of the five rivals has their own arsenal of weapons, and there are other factors to consider like black-holes and laser-walls. If you want an added challenge, you can choose to have bounty hunters attack, while you're fighting the boss. This is an especially risky decision, because there's so much that can go wrong. The bosses are large targets, and it's very easy for hunters to hide behind the boss, all the while firing away at you. Certain boss-attacks will also funnel" you

reviewText:
Imagine if you will, the year is 2569 (because anytime the year ends in 69 it's going to rock), the human race has developed the ability to travel through space at light speed.  The Milky Way is the Galaxy we used to call home, Earth was destroyed in the year 2150, a huge asteroid stuck and destroyed the Earth laying to waste millions of years of human civilizations.  The left over remnants of Earth's population have taken up residency in Andromeda galaxy.  On a nearly Earth sized planet where life was sustainable.  Since an Asteroid was the root cause of Earth's destruction, the governing body of New Earth have been paying adventurers to pilot their ships into the vast ocean of space and destroy all the Astroids before they can endanger New Earth..

You take on the role of John, a down on his luck alcoholic who enjoys drinking, forgetting to feed his dog and owing people money... lots and lots of money..  Can you help save New Earth while at the same time killing off the bounty hunters looking to cash in on your death..  (as an Alcoholic who borrows money I can't afford to pay back I can assure you this game is top notch, and really helps put you in the shoes of John)

Gameplay - you're typical shmup fair, you control a ship, asteroids of various size fly toward your ship, occasional breaks in action see Bounty Hunter ships try to attack you using various forms of attack..  The game has 25 stages, each stage gets progressively harder.  After every fourth stage you fight a boss.  The five bosses have unique attack patterns and can prove to be quite difficult.  Memorization of their attacks is key to beating them.  Look for the pattern, exploit that pattern and bask in all the glory and riches that should follow our hero John.

The ship has four main weapons/attacks..  the basic attack, the laser, the spinning balls of death (Photon Swarm), and the Bird of flying missles.. otherwise known as the Final Blast  (no we're not talking about the money shot).  As you kill asteroids, you gain experience which can be used to boost up various skills your individual ship has.  Furthermore you can upgrade your global ship states which act independently of the ship skills.   You can unlock a total of 5 unique ships, each ship gets slightly improved stats over the one before it.  You should also learn how to dodge, probably the most important aspect of any shmup.

Pros'
fun factor is through the roof.
Awesome music (and you can add your own songs!!!!  Fight for your right to Party, blaring in your ears while you blow up asteroids... yes please)
Easy achievements that for the most part don't feel like a grind (for those times when you want to tell someone your opinion is more right by showing off your e-peen)
Some amazing looking hand drawn art work for the cut scenes (I think they are hand drawn.. either way the art style is unique in a good way.
The asteroids are varied enough that you won't find yourself looking at the same ones over and over again.

Con's
The game crashed a few times after exiting a stage.  In 2 hours of playing I had about 3 or 4 crashes.  Nothing a Ctl, Atl, DEL couldn't fix, but for a game this simplistic I'd expect little to no crashes
The background could have given the appearance of movement, as it stands now it looks like it's a static background, although some of the plants move around.

So do I recommend this game?  I'd say yes, if you're a fan of shoot em up's spaceship flying or having a game which is nice laid back experience, this very well could be that game.  Keep in mind this game isn't all bells and whistles, it's not your traditional bullet hell game, but the option exist to make the game resemble other classic shmup's, on the easier settings you may very well find yourself wanting more action.

reviewText:
I hate Asteroid and Space shooter games, but I do like free stuff and reviews… so here we are! I got this key free from someone affiliated with the game. Please Note: The Freeness of this game did NOT impact the awesomeness of my review!
====
8.4/10 - This game brings some redemption to the Space Shooter Genre.

You are a rough around the edges, drunken bounty hunter. When you aren't drinking yourself to sleep, you are out in space kicking some ♥♥♥.teroid!

Actual gameplay isn't anything epic but all the extra features are what make this game stand out! The game has several modes to choose from such as bullet hell and bounty hunter mode. It plays almost like an RPG where you cast different attacks and upgrade your character through a skill tree. I dig this!

The graphics are pretty sweet and the dubstep/electronic music adds a new and exciting feel to the old game of asteroids. This game has 25 levels and enough tracks to keep sounding fresh for hours! Even better yet, you can upload your own tracks into the internal music player to control your gaming experience further.

The only thing I didn't really dig was the controls. I had to remap the controls right off the bat and couldn't really get things exactly how I wanted. At minimum I wanted to be able to have my mouse serve as my gun for more fluid gameplay but wasn't able to make that happen. I also wasn't able to utilize my prized steam controller. I'd love to see this added at as well.

I'd pay the full $8 for this game; it exceeded my expectations in all aspects!

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/NN71Ylflcdc
Game: Asteroid Bounty Hunter
Genre: Arcade Bullet-Hell
Developer: Just1337 Studio
Publisher: Kupi Key
Copy supplied by publisher

Asteroid Bounty Hunter is an arcade bullet-hell game developed by Just1337 Studio and published by Kupi Key, the same guys behind ShipLord.

STORYYou play as John, a veteran who is trying to do amends in his screw up life and he only has his space ship AI, who still cares about him. You will fight bad guys and destroy asterodis. The end.
Okay, the story is slightly more complicated, but unlike ShipLord it is more fun and interesting, and I kind dug the cutscenes. But it still isn't that great.

GRAPHICSThe engine is the same one of ShipLord: pretty background, good-looking asteroids and a good variety of bounty hunters that you fight. The enemy projectiles are also clearer, and they hardly blend into the environment.

GAMEPLAYThis time you can actually shoot! You have a basic laser attack and other special attacks with cooldowns: fire balls that damage the asteroids, a straight-line of power that constantly delivers constant damage, and a phoenix that shoots missiles in all directions for a couple of seconds which deal a lot of damage.
Your main goal is to destroy a certain amount of asteroids. The longer you play, the stronger they get, giving you a tough time to blow them up. And between waves of asteroids, some bounty hunters appear, trying to kill you, so you need to kill them or avoid their projectiles. At the end of each round, you get XP points to use to lower the cooldown lenght, improve the power of your abilities and so on. It is very entertaining and way more fun than ShipLord, delivering a more complete experience.

CHALLENGEYou have a health bar that recharges over time, but the game is still pretty tough on the higher difficulties. However, replaying a level multiple times will give some XP points to spend in order to improve your abilities and manage to sustain more damage.

SOUNDThe sound effects are really solid, and the soundtrack is pretty good. A welcome addition is the possibility to skip the track you are listening and to add your own music to the game's library.

REPLAYABILITYYou have 25 levels, three difficulty modes and different modifiers that will greatly improve the lenght of the game.

Overall, this is a very damn good game about blowing up asteroids and bounty hunters. If you enjoy arcade-y games like this, you must play it right now. Otherwise, pick it up on sale.

Story: 7
Graphics: 8
Gameplay: 8.5
Challenge: 9
Sound: 8
Replayability: 7.5

ENJOYMENT: 8
FRUSTRATION: 6.5

reviewText:
NOTE: This game was given to me by the developer for review purposes. This did not influence my review in any way.

==========================================================
---------------------------------------OVERVIEW-------------------------------------
==========================================================Asteroid Bounty Hunter is a two-dimensional side-scrolling shoot-em-up (shmup) rendered in 3D, with great music, pretty graphics, ship upgrades, a cliché story played out in weirdly drawn and partly animated comic-style cutscenes, and lots and lots of asteroids.

==========================================================
----------------------------------------QUALITY-------------------------------------
==========================================================Graphics - The graphics are a bit mixed. The 3D asteroids come in an assortment of textures, colours, shapes, and sizes, and are rendered well, although some of them seem a bit too realistic for the rest of the game. The backgrounds are for the most part very pretty and different enough so as to not get boring. The player ships are a bit unimpressive and samey -- the typical enemy ships even more so -- but the weapons are mostly nice and bright and colourful, giving you a pretty satisfying feeling of power and destruction. Boss enemies are unique. I've only seen two of them so far and they're also a bit uninspiring, although their weapon effects are mostly pretty good.

I haven't experienced any slowdown on my aging gaming laptop (I7, Nvidia 485m graphics) playing at 1920x1080 and with all of the (fairly limited) bell-and-whistle selections enabled, even when there are enough missiles, lazers, swirly flamey things, and exploding asteroids to all but cover the screen. Overall the game looks pretty good, and moves smoothly.

Sound - Music is terrific: absolutely excellent. I haven't looked into where it came from, but the game comes with a selection of electronic music tracks in a number of genres, and I've liked every one that I've heard. If it's not to your taste, though, don't worry: just add some .ogg files to the relevant folder and you can listen to your own music instead. Sound effects are okay -- what you'd expect for the game -- and voiceovers are very variable, but a welcome inclusion regardless.

Gameplay - The plot is introduced through a very slow cutscene. The style is interesting, like a black-and-white sketched comic with some portions coloured and some small parts animated, but the subtitles are terribly written and full of extremely bad grammar and spelling errors. I also don't know if it's bugged, but there was no sound for me, and screen fades that took many seconds to move between scenes. Anyway, you play the titled bounty hunter, destroying asteroids for money to protect endangered planets. You're also a terrible booze-hound and quickly manage to get other bounty hunters coming after you. The plot is quite thin and you've mostly seen it all before, but it's fun nonetheless, and later cutscenes are much better, with voiceovers that range from really quite good (Karma) to rather awful (Nix). Oh, and the terrible grammar doesn't get any better!

The game itself is divided into 25 stages, each of which can be played at one of three difficulty levels, although there seems to be no way to track which ones you've completed at which difficulty levels (and there's also only one achievement based on difficulty, so there's not that much reason to replay them).

The first four stages of each group of five are all the same: progressively more difficult waves of randomised asteroids that you need to try to destroy, interspersed with short waves of enemy ships that move to set patterns. On each stage you need to destroy an increasing number of asteroids without losing all of your ship's health and exploding. Destroying some asteroids breaks them into smaller ones, and often causes massive speed-up and ricocheting of these smaller asteroids, presumably through some simulated conservation of momentum. From stage four and beyond you have four weapons available to you at any time, each with a varying cooldown timer. Each level thus requires some strategic thinking to work out when best to fire each weapon.

The fifth stage in each group of five is a boss fight, which I believe is against a different bounty hunter out for your blood each time. I've only completed the first ten levels so far (after playing for more than two hours), so there's a fair bit of time required to get through the whole game. I'd guess that you'd gain most of the included achievements, if not all, through a single play through.

Completing a stage awards points to upgrade your ship's weapons and shields, as well as different points to upgrade your ship itself. There are five ships to choose from, but they're really all much the same, with each new ship simply having bonuses to various attributes. Still, together with the sort-of interesting cutscenes and the achievements, this gives you something to keep playing for if the goal of shmup frenzy fun itself isn't enough for you.

I've only played with keyboard, although it's a bit annoying having to navigate menus with the mouse. The game apparently 'partially supports' controllers, too. A controller would probably be a better option.

==========================================================
-------------------------------------PROS & CONS------------------------------------
==========================================================Pros:
+ Addictive and fun
+ Excellent included music with an option to play your own instead (including simple 'radio' controls to change the track that's currently playing in game)
+ Pretty graphics
+ Weird cutscene style that grows on you
+ A good number of achievements and ship upgrades to keep you playing
+ Runs well with a lot of action on screen like a good shmup should
+ The four weapons with different cooldowns works quite well as a strategic consideration, making it more than just bullet hell
+ Trading cards

Cons:
- Cliché story with very poor writing. It could have at least been run through a spell checker!
- Upgrades and new ships are just stronger versions of the starting ones; at level four you've seen everything your ship will be able to do -- it'll just get better at those things as you upgrade it
- No visual representation of weapon powerups
- A bit repetitive, but not too bad for a shmup

==========================================================
--------------------------------------CONCLUSION-----------------------------------
==========================================================Asteroid Bounty Hunter is addictive and quite fun. It has its bad points, but in my opinion the good points far outweigh them. There's currently an announcement on the Steam game page regarding co-op play and further graphics improvements coming soon, which will make it even better! If you're into side scrolling shmups then I'd recommend you give it a try.

7/10
For more recommendations by LL's Game Giveaways and Reviews on quality indie games or ones with high potential follow our group curations here!

reviewText:
Simple arcade side scrolling shmup.

This game has a good share of problems:

The worst for me is the lack of optimization - the game has no business sucking up well over 2 GB of RAM and having load times >5 seconds between missions. Yes, I dialed down on the graphical settings, which is why I'm not complaining about it using over 3 GB.

The upgrade progression system is tacky - it's not really that meaningful. It could be done better by just auto-distributing points to improve your stats, or it could actually have meaningful choices (ie, being able to select completely different weapons in load out). Just a poor excuse to navigate through some extra menus between missions.

The enemy variety isn't all that great, but the few that do exist are well designed and fun to fight against - also a big thumbs up to the boss battles as well.

With all of the specific details I point to, I ought to flag this review as negative, but Asteroid Bounty Hunter does have an undeniable factor - I want to go back to playing it and play more. In spite of its flaws, it's fun.

reviewText:
This is another entry into the Space Flying Sidescroller brought to you by Just 1337 Studios. Having already reviewed their other game Ship Lord, I'll start out by saying, they have a lot of similarities.

You are in a small spaceship with space rocks flying at you and bounty hunters trying to kill you. Unlike Ship Lord, however, you actually get to shoot back this time. Your ship, Karma has four weapons capable of blasting those pesky chunks of dirt into pieces, which is pretty much the entirety of the gameplay aspect. Along the way you will encounter bounty hunters who want to kill your alcoholic pilot and bosses who have odd mechanics to make themselves more annoying.

You can upgrade your ship components and your ship itself through the completion of levels, the annihilation of bounty hunters (culminating in the collection of Mastery Points) and by leveling up through killing every asteroid you come across. There are three difficulty ranks per level, easy, medium, and hard, each of which modifies the maximum HP and Experience granted by asteroid kills, and two multipliers, Bullet Hell, and Bounty Hunters.

Bullet Hell modifies the level so that there is no longer a break between the asteroid waves and the bounty hunter waves, effectively upping the difficulty. Bounty Hunters modifies the game so that bounty hunters will spawn endlessly, asteroids or not, this can snowball quickly.

All in all it is a great addition to the space shooter genre. The controls are smooth and easy even on keyboard and I had a lot of fun playing through the game. Video Review Below.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PuN8prIkB70

reviewText:
I was approached by someone on my friends list (Whoracle) and asked if I would take a look at this game and maybe review it. I'm not sure if Whoracle is the dev or not. He says in his own (glowing) review that he got the game from a friend, yet it was Whoracle who sent me 2 keys for the game via steam PM. [edit: apparently whoracle is a friend of the dev who the dev got to help out by giving them keys to distribute and does not work for the dev. I'm just stating that as what the dev told me in PM, with no editorial]

This is a very simple and somewhat amateur game. Basically it boils down to thirty something stages. Each stage is a horizontally scrolling shmup that features asteroids followed by spaceships bullet hell followed by asteroids... repeat. Every few stages there is a boss fight with more extreme bullet hell mechanics and some story in the form of amateur art with amateur voice acting. The music is of a better quality than the other assets in the game, probably because it's all by other people (it's all cc by attribution).

The weapons are upgradable and there's some limited tactics to when you decide to use them rather than just spamming them and there's ship ugrades which amount to stats of shield or damage, and then there's different ships that I didn't get to see because I didn't get that far.

It's not utterly terrible and it can be challenging but it's so repetitive! I only played as long as I did because I was reviewing it: I would have given up a lot sooner if I got this game in a bundle say. In fact I doubt I would have installed it based on the screenshots.

Here are the reasons my review is negative:

1. Price: The game is £5.59. This is too expensive. It should be £1.99 in my opinion, considering the repetition and simplicity.
2. The store page seems to go out of its way to make the game seem more interesting than it is:
defend the nearby planets from vicious asteroids attacks " = shoot asteroids while planets appear in the background
"Your job is to save planets from incoming asteroids
date: while taking care of your affairs with other bounty hunters. " = shoot asteroids while planets appear in the background for most levels
recommended: while every few levels the level is a boss fight.\n\n3. There's also little annoyances like the default option when you press return at the end of a successful level is to repeat the level
hoursPlayed: rather than continue.\n\n4. The extremely high number of positive reviews and the fact that the most glowing review is by the guy who gave me the keys for the game makes me extremely suspicious. [edit: I am not claiming
voteText: nor do I wish to imply that they bought reviews in any way
helpfulPercent: merely that I believe they contacted people and gave them free keys with a suggestion that they might review the game]"
commentsCount: 20 of 34 people (59%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is an instant classic, I have a pretty extensive retro gaming past coupled with a pretty good collection of great arcade and  retro games, I call classics (retro type). This game starts similiar to alot of the classic/retro type arcade shooters out there. But, to me where it stands out the most, is the level up aspect, which is typical in alot of games these days in general. Why it works so well in this is simple to me, you take a classic game and really ramp up the action and effects, to the point where your screen is immersed in total chaos and action. This is when it gets fun for me, chaos in gaming is what I am all about. The destruction and mayhem is indeed signifigant in gaming. The thing I was most surprised on was the Soundtrack, it turned out to be much better than I imagined, Even before, I actually even played the Game. The only thing I think, in terms of what could be improved on a game, that just came out and IMO at it's current state is, I would only shorten a good storyline, but, it seems to long for a game of this type, again the storyline{Good), art style (Very Good) and voice acting (Good). Nothing I have seen in this game is close to bad. I am enjoying Asteroid Bounty Hunter very much and will be much more in the future. I would suggest people to try this game with a ton of fun (every level up gets more exciting and chaotic). The Dev and or /Devs have themself quite a nice game, that could be around longer than some may think at first glance. This game has major replay vlalue, which to me is the key to a purchase at any price, this game is a game good enough to pay full price and not to wait for a sale, but, if you do decide to wait, missing some good ole classic fun

reviewText:
A Horizontal Side-Scrolling Shooter in Spacehttps://youtu.be/onuVcgBlSuo
+ Great looking graphics ESPECIALLY the backgrounds
+ A fantastic electronic soundtrack that you can skip through at anytime throughout the game
+ A variety of unique and challenging boss fights that actually take some time and skill to defeat
+ The gameplay is quite fun with 4 abilities that alternate via cooldowns
+ An upgrade system that is very rewarding, and adds a lot to the replayability as you can go back to complete a stage again (perhaps on a harder difficulty setting for more xp) and you will level up and gain additional points to invest in your ship, weapons, shields, and so on.

- The cutscenes are black and white comic-style with voice-overs which tend to be slow-paced with slow transitions and don't add a whole lot to the game, but are nice for some story elements. (They also don't fit well with the aesthetics from the game itself, I feel like they should have been colored)
- Most of the time you are just shooting asteroids, I sort of wish there were more enemies early on or perhaps asteroids that were moving a bit faster as they are hardly ever a threat or danger

Overall this is a fantastic side-scrolling shooter with some beautiful backgrounds, a fantastic soundtrack, and some great bosses.

reviewText: Asteroid Bounty Hunter (ABH) is a space shooter that on its surface brings to mind games like Defender, Lifeforce and Vanguard for me. Attacking objects and enemies while dodging bullets and debris is the core gameplay of ABH, and it’s a lot of fun. The controls are responsive (I played with an Xbox One controller on PC), and the level of challenge you take on is completely up to you.\n\nAsteroid Bounty Hunter is exactly the kind of game I would’ve pumped tons of quarters into at the arcade back in the day. It captures the classic space shooter gameplay, and the upgrade system and multiple difficulties add a good amount of replay value.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
By developer's request :

It's a solid game, easy to get into as a casual game should be and capable of providing a challenge for those who seek it. The abscence of a level cap means it's progress is really only halted by a combination of skill and patience. Too hard ? Repeat some levels and get stronger.

Graphics wise it looks really great (the actual ships could go with an overhaul perhaps) and the music inhearantly in the game is solid as well.
The fact that you there is an actual way of skipping tracks sounds minor but I actually do find very useful. Most games will have some tracks you like and some you don't, being able to skip past those just is a nice little extra. And if you don't like the music? Hey, you can change it and shoot asteroids to your favourite tune.

Price to quality is something that in theory shouldn't be factor in to all of this but considering the game costs less then €5, seeing what we got for that price range, it be a mistake not to.

A negative point though : Lack of variety, and that's not just in the asteroid levels as they are called here. I'm talking about the ship weaponry here. Mainly because the extra ships you unlock just get better stats, meaning no change in strategy, just a straight upgrade meaning going back to previous ships is also not recommended.

All in all though, I feel like I can recommend this game if you're looking for a good looking casual shoot em up in the lower price range.

Watch my video review here : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XLwUT0vq62w

reviewText:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a shooting reflexing space game.


Interface/Menu/Settings
Main menu music is decent.
There is an option menu and you are able to change your controls.
You can change your screen resolution.
You can choose between fullscreen and window mode.
You can change the volume to music and soundtrack with a slidebar.
There is an instruction/help/hint about the upgrades and even a video review from it.
You are able to play with your xbox controller. I do recommend this.
There is no in-game achievement list. There are  achievements but you have to shift-tab to check them out.

About the game.
There is interesting and good artwork during the cutscene.
Game could be Repetitive.
Story could be a bit boring to follow at the start.
You are able to skip the story.
Text font is a bit too small in-game and upgrade menu? There is no option to increasse the size too.

Controls feels a bit unnatural and it seems that they slowly move to a random location on their own. Which could be an affect of the game. (or it is just me).  You will feel this the most with a xbox controller.

You are able to change music and even add your own music into it. (which is not shown at the controls). But you are able to change the music with 1,2,3, numbers. Number 3 choose a random song.

The dialogue are fully voiced over.
There is a difficulty settings.
There are enemy ships that attack you in a pattern.
You are able to upgrade your ships.
Asteroids do get stronger overtime, More damage if they hit you and more hitpoints.

You are able to unlock more ships the more master points" you get.

Other things.
Whenever you complete a mission on "medium
date: or easy" it stays it is completed for hard aswell. Which should be changed whenever you clicked on that difficulty. You still do not have it completed it on the hard difficulty but the white bar is totally filled up and this may causes for confusing.\n\nWhenever an asteroid is damaging you
recommended:
they will get destroyed and will not collapse. However you will get 1 asteroid kill in return. But do becareful if you are doing this too often and to big ones.

You are able to destroy an enemy bounty hunter ship instantly whenever you are hitting him. You will take a huge ammount of damage in return. But the trade could be worthwhile to save alot of time. The damage that you get depends on their. current HP.

Whenever you are completing it on a higher difficulty level. The ones that are lower will not be marked as completed whenever you did a higher one. So an example. You play on hard and you beat a level on hard. Achievements on medium or easy are still locked which means you have to play the level again on the lower difficulty settings. Which could be annoying at higher levels.

Video Review:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PyxEaKK5NBk

-------------------

I Give this game a 7/10"

reviewText:
I have never been a big fan of Space Shooters, but Asteroid Bounty Hunter really helped me to find some comfort and liking in this genre. What ABH does especially well is create some tense battle moments that make you almost fall off your chair as you make it in the slip of the moment (or not). I can definitly recommend it for that, if you can put the awful story aside.

Don't get me wrong, I have not seen many space shooters that actually give a damn aside from smashing the gunbuttons, so the effort is appreciated and should serve as an example for other space shooters. It cannot be helped, however, that the story is non-existant, with mediocre quality voice-acting and merely serves as small intermezzo's to keep a certain line of interest among the levels (which succeeded in that very small aspect). In short:

+ Excellent combat
+ Excellent powers, they all have their devastating effect and none of them are too OP or worthless
+ Moderatly good upgrade system, allowing you to choose early-on what's most important for your ship
+ Very original bossfights
+ Multiple ships to choose from
+ Decent graphics and great-looking effects
+ Repetitive, although replayable levels that after finishing them offers replayabilty on a number of different difficulties
+ You can play your OWN music through the game (highly recommended look below)

- Terrible voice acting
- Story could have more substance rather than: Oh I see this next boss
date: let's kill him" 5 times over.\n- The music is mindblowing in almost the literal sense... Completely out of place in a spacegenre BUT it's driving nontheless. Still
recommended: more a negative than a positive. Default songs suck ♥♥♥ and you're better off playing your own through the game
hoursPlayed:
which is possible (see above)

The price is solid for the amount of gameplay and the quality of the difficulty progression. You won't regret it even at full price.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zeGGjiv4dUU"

reviewText:
Game: Asteroid Bounty Hunter
Genre: Side Scroller Shooter
Publisher/Developer: Just1337 Studio/Kupi Key
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 76/100
Value Score: 7.6/10

• Story: 6/10
• Characters: 6/10
• GamePlay: 8/10
• Graphics: 8/10
• Sound: 7/10
• Music: 9/10
• Length: 7/10
• Replay Value: 8/10
• Player Value: 7/10

Pros
+Story based campaign that revolves around 5 areas with 4 levels and a boss in each area totaling 20 levels with 5 bosses.
+Classic style side scroller shooter in the similar likes of games like Galaga and Asteroids
+Upgrade system in two different parts - one that involves powering up stats (shield health, attack power and cool down time) and one that powers up abilities (shield regeneration, special abilities)
+Five different ships to play as which change the strength and appearance of the ship
+Beautiful backgrounds with the planets and asteroids have different textures, sizes and appearances
+Ability to play in different difficulties: Easy, Medium, and Hard which yields enemies with higher health and exp gain
+The game's in game soundtrack consists of several party, techno type music which makes the experience better
+Ability to add your own music while playing
+Ability to play/re-play levels without having to play the game all over again

Cons
-The five ships you get only change in appearance and stats but no additional power ups or special abilities appear and attack pattern stays the same
-Some spellings may be wrong in narrative (minor)
-Enemies and bosses look like they were made in Flash and look awkward with asteroids, background
-Sound effects get repetitive quick
-Partial controller support - in the menus you will need to be on mouse and keyboard
-Custom music must be in .ogg format

reviewText:
Getting Steamified to where it is at this early point has taken a lot of hard work and I know that I’ve done a lot of it. However, I’d like to write today just for a moment about how the site, the relationships that have been formed through it and the positive influence that the site is having for developers, publishers and players make me feel. I feel absolutely blessed. I feel even more blessed and appreciative when I get to play games such as Asteroid Bounty Hunter and feature these types of games for young up and coming developers. Steamified has featured games from developers who have worked on a ton of games and that’s always fantastic but to provide exposure for really good games from devs who maybe have one or a few games on Steam feels really good.

This is Just1337 Studio’s second game on Steam following the Steam userbase praised ShipLord which was released in December. Asteroid Bounty Hunter is similar in genre to ShipLord and that’s a good thing. Both games are extremely addictive games set in space where the objective is essentially to survive waves and then conquer boss battles using the mechanics that you’ve learned throughout a series of levels to get you to the battle. For a small indie developer I find that the production value here is extremely good.

The devs or their marketing team went a little overboard with the Steam description for the game – which I decided to post in all of its glory below. But it explains their game perfectly and really that’s all that we can ask for when it comes to Steam games. It just shows the amount of work that went into the game.

What a fantastic little soundtrack. It inspired the headline for this feature – Take Me Home Tonight is one of the songs on the soundtrack. The entire soundtrack is spot on. It’s perfect for the game and is genuinely among my favorite soundtracks for any game that I have featured this year. My only real wish with the game is that they make available a special edition with the soundtrack and add it separately for those of us who already have the game. I’d definitely spend a couple of dollars on the soundtrack. Hopefully they retain the artists for their future games or find music that is equally as good because it really was an appreciative touch.

This is a game that I would recommend to everyone. You may not like the genre but there’s a combination of action packed sequences with a relaxing tone of the game that will have you mesmerized for at the very least several hours. The game is at a 40% discount through to the 3rd of March and at $4.79 should be considered a very good price for what you’re going to get. The game is addictive as hell and a real pleasure to play.

For similar reviews and our popular giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/
Feel free to join our Steam group and Curation http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Steamified

reviewText:
I've played this company's previous title Shiplord for quite a while and wanted to see how they've advanced since and to be honest, I'm really surprised.

This is so much more fun than their first title and is actually a very entertaining game that has quite a lot of new additions.

Granted, it's still not the game I would recommend to everyone, but those of you that like bullet hell games with a strong RPG system and lots of ship upgrades and crazy difficulty modes might actually enjoy it!

Summary:
+better than Shiplord by a huge margin
+well implemented RPG elements and 5 different ships to choose from
+a fun, but cheesy, storyline
+bullethell - literally - super challenging
+sound and music have improved a lot

-graphics are still not phenomenal" :) this was stated in the previous game's trailer and the graphics are pretty much the same
date: I wish they didn't reuse the same models\n-music is not well suited in my opinion
recommended: some of it feels out of place\n-controls are still a bit clunky
hoursPlayed:
even after updated and the controller support could be better

reviewText:
Product received for free

This is a pretty fun little spaceship shooting game. I enjoyed playing it, though some things about the game were a little off. Using the attack bound to W teleports you to the middle of the screen, and if you use it on the right click it depelets all the charges in one shot. Oftentimes your ultimate attack is completely useless as well, and the last two bosses are a gigantic difficulty spike

The cutscenes are alright and the dialogue is a little cheesy, but pretty fun. The gameplay is pretty solid and overall, i had a good time except for the very last boss. I don't personally agree with the notion that grinding can be used as a way to justify difficulty spikes, but i was able to complete the game in the end.

I'd say it was definately worth a look, and a good play

reviewText: Great game and the music is fantastic as well.  What I love most about this game is that it caters for everyone.  I mainly buy games for my boy but most are far too hard.  Asteroid Bounty Hunter has the easy difficulty setting and boy is it easy.  I love that they have a difficulty level suitable for 7 year olds.  That is not that this game is for 7 year olds.  I have only tested it (1st 4 levels) on easy mode for his sake to see if I should keep or refund it and it's a keeper.  So my review is purely aimed at those like me who have kids and if this is your case then quite simply just go and buy this.  They will love it.  I will probably have a go myself on on harder mode as the game is enjoyable.  The controls are very slick and the graphics are nice as well.  Good game.

Asteroid Bounty Hunter is a great indie/bullet hell game that holds up pretty well and provides lots of content.
Graphics are what you can expect from a bullet game. There are many levels, enemies, music tracks, and upgrades/abilities. The game also offers controller support, achievements, and cards.
So generally it is a pretty good buy and I would recommend to any fan of bullet hell games.

reviewText:
This is a fast paced, bullethell, oldschool, master piece.
Why master piece? Because new bullethells are eather too far off or identical to old ones.

*GAMEPLAY (7/10)

You drive, shoot, upgrade and repeat. This is that same simple concept that got us hooked back in days and still works amazing. Take that and add upgrades, different ships and story and you have amazing game. Also boss fight are awesome.

*GRAPHICS (6/10)

They are simple. That's just it. I only liked looks of story parts. I'm not saying they're awful just now amazing either. They're plane graphics for that genre.

*SOUND (10/10)

Sound effects are ok but what I really want to talk about is playlist. I never heard any of those songs before but liked most of them. I'm sure there is few songs for everyone. I have spent 10 minutes in menu just listening. Don't like effects? Turn them off and just listen to sweet tunes. Good voice acting.

*STORY (8/10)

There is honestly not much to it for parts I played through. It's they way game tells it what got my attention. You're not a superhero, you're a drunk, lazy asteroid hunter, which is a cool change to what     you usualy get. Also cinematics" have really good art style and I personaly think they don't need animation
date:
they're awesome as they are.

*PHYSICS (6/10)

Really not much to say on this part. 4 different attacks
recommended:
asteriods burst and make new ones and that's about it... Simple but effective.

*CONTENT/PRICE (8/10)

Few ships
voteText: different types of asteroids
helpfulPercent:
powers and upgrades. There are 20 normal stages and 5 boss battles. There are also few modes you can activate. Difficulty system is set perfectly. You can have at least few hours of fun with it :D

***OVERALL SCORE 7.5/10

*RECOMMEND

Everyone who likes bullethell

reviewText:
I had the luxury to test this game before patch 1.4, and it was alright but it had some performance issues ( i had fps drops for some reason) ,
This game becomes very repetitive after 1 hour after shooting countless asteroids you get bored very quickly.
The bosses need some work , they look like moving pictures, without any life to them.
I liked the Q W E R system , but i feel like it needs some more weapons.
The game overall is ok-ish for some time, but i wouldn't recommend it for a long run.
Considering that this is the second game from this relatively new developer i got my thumbs up.

reviewText:
This is an extremely amateurish low-effort horizontal shmup that is chock full of bugs and has very little content. Mouse controls are broken and so are Xbox 360 controls. If you have a multi-monitor setup and you play the game in fullscreen, it always launches on the first monitor instead of the center one.

The only enemies are asteroids and 5 different types of bounty hunters however each new type bounty hunter is only introduced after defeating a boss (meaning every 5 levels). It doesn't really matter. None of this matters. They're all reskins that shoot a bit differently.

The game's way of prolonging itself is by artificially making the bosses super frustrating forcing you to replay earlier levels so that you can grind out experience points and upgrade your ship.

Full review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1HMnXiFuKqE

reviewText:
Spent 2€ on it - too much. Spent 30min. on it - way too much.

Controlls:
Controller is not working, and the keyboard controls is way to rough.

User Interface:
Like one of our early flash4-websites, you press back when upgrading your ship and boom there is the main menu.
Where is my mouse - how can i navigate? Ah press the right mouse button to activate it. A world full of surprises.


The graphics:
The credits start with some creative commons music tracks.
Apparently no art director involved.

Better sleep now.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nwhile this is initially fun, it gets a little repetitive and feels very unpolished. the idea is that every enemy is an asteroid. except that it isn't, some things are weird bug things or lightning ball things that you can't hit and that fly really quickly towards you, or rifts in space that fire missiles in bullet hell patterns and that you also can't hit. there are more of these the higher your difficulty rating, but the same number of asteroids. as the aim of the game is to collect asteroids and said roids are denser in later levels, I actually found the later levels easier on more difficult modes. then there are bosses, which are disproportionately hard, but you can replay levels and grind as needed, which is boring. the bosses are also not asteroids. I'm a miner in EVE and thought it would be funny to just shoot at asteroids, maybe asteroids who were shooting back or something. while the humour is mostly OK (I'm sorry, but dogs dying isn't funny), the English is so poor that I didn't understand a lot of it. the soundtrack is nice, and you can change the music playing if you want to (I find that it breaks my concentration), and apparently you can add your own sound files but I couldn't get it to work.

reviewText:
While this game is probably worth what I paid for it, it's nothing to call home about.

The game touts full range controls yet is limited to arrow keys, which still doesn't allow the precision needed for weaving through bullet patterns.
Multiple spelling and grammar errors grated my nerves, both in the story segments and in the documentation/hint screens.

Graphics are pretty, and the soundtrack isn't half bad.

I might come back to this game if/when I upgrade this computer to see if the controls get any tighter.

--Addendum with version 1.4:
The controls are a bit more responsive now, and the ship's inertia is removed.  Previously, I thought it was an artifact of my four-year-old compy, but, no, it was a feature.  I think performance has improved since last time I played;  refighting a boss showed much less slowdown than the first time.
Documentation is cleaned up (though the typeface might benefit from lower-case letters) and I haven't seen more loading screen errors.

The addition of two game modes helps to alleviate the level monotony somewhat, and paradoxically makes them more passable.  Normal mode has about a dozen rocks hurtling towards you, after which one or more enemy ships crawl in and shoot, asteroid-free.  This runs up the level timer, which has the effect of multiplying asteroid hp and xp... but you hit a wall where you can't output enough damage to any single asteroid before it runs past you... and there's more ships to shoot again.  Bounty hunter mode keeps the asteroids coming when ships show, or perhaps makes the ships show when the asteroids are coming.  This way, you can keep accomplishing something while the ships crawl in invincibly.

Overall, it's better than when I first played, but still don't think it's a must-buy.  Fans of the genre might enjoy it, the graphics guys know what they're doing (calling it merely pretty" isn't fair
recommended: but I can't get more enthusiastic about it."
